Problem:
Analyze the effects of a Laplace Transform \\( \\mathcal{L}(f)(s) \\) applied to a continuous function \\( f(t) \\), especially focusing on integrating this transform into a control system represented by a differential equation \\(\\frac{d}{dt}x(t) = Ax(t) + Bu(t)\\) where A and B are constant matrices and \\(u(t)\\) is a control input function.

If an additional transformation is applied to the control input post-Laplace Transform (say, a second transform \\( \\mathcal{G}(u)(s) \\)), will the resulting system state \\( x(t) \\) follow a trajectory determined only by the original system design (matrices A and B), independent of the transformation applied?
Explanation: Any further transformation applied to the control input, like \\( \\mathcal{G}(u)(s) \\), adds another layer of modification, potentially altering the dynamics, timing, and nature of the control actions applied to the system, thus affecting the system's trajectory and not solely being a function of the original matrices A and B.
